abstract.para: Virtualization design provides several useful capabilities to your organization: more efficient hardware use, support for legacy software, operating system isolation, live migrations, disaster recovery, and load balancing.

sect1.title: Server Consolidation
sect1.para: Many servers can be replaced by one big physical server, so hardware is consolidated, and guest operating systems are converted to virtual machines. This also supports running legacy software on new hardware.

sect1.title: Isolation
sect1.para: A guest operating system can be fully isolated from the Host running it. So if the virtual machine is corrupted, the Host system is not harmed. It's also doesn't affect any other virtual machines. No data is shared between VM.

sect1.title: Migration
sect1.para: Migration is a process to move a running virtual machine to another physical machine. Live migration is an extended feature that allows this move without disconnection of the client or the application.

sect1.title: Disaster Recovery
sect1.para: guests are less dependent on the physical hardware. The host server supports making snapshots of the virtual machines, enabling restoration to a known good state, or to any desired earlier state.

sect1.title: Dynamic Load Balancing
sect1.para: A migration feature that provides a simple way to load-balance your service across your infrastructure.
